candidates.definition: Anatomical formations that are distinct structural components or divisions within an organism's body.

positive_examples: The thoracic cavity houses the heart and lungs.
The elbow joint allows the arm to bend and extend.
Each segment of the insect's abdomen can move independently.
The orbital socket protects the eye from injury.
The ankle joint connects the leg to the foot.
The vertebral segments make up the spine's structure.
negative_examples: The skin covers the entire surface of the body.
Blood flows through the circulatory system.
The liver produces bile for digestion.
Muscles contract to create movement.
Nerve impulses travel to the brain.
The heart pumps blood throughout the body.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: BodyTissue, BodySystem, BodyFluid, BodySurface

candidates.definition: Anatomical divisions of the brain with distinct functions and locations within the cranium.

positive_examples: The MRI scan showed damage to the frontal lobe affecting decision-making abilities.
Researchers found increased activity in the temporal lobes during memory recall tasks.
The stroke patient had lesions in the parietal lobe causing spatial awareness problems.
Neurosurgeons carefully mapped the occipital lobe before removing the tumor.
The hypothalamus regulates body temperature and hormone production.
Brain imaging revealed abnormal connections between the medulla and pons.
negative_examples: The spinal cord carries signals between the brain and peripheral nerves.
Cranial nerves control facial muscles and sensory functions.
The skull protects the brain from external trauma and injury.
Cerebrospinal fluid cushions the brain within the cranial cavity.
Blood vessels supply oxygen and nutrients to brain tissue.
The meninges are protective membranes surrounding the brain.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Muscles, Bones, Organs, Limbs, Joints

candidates.definition: Microscopic biological structures including cells and their component parts

positive_examples: The mitochondria produces energy for the cell
Scientists observed the cell membrane under a microscope
The virus capsid protects its genetic material
Ribosomes synthesize proteins within the cytoplasm
The nucleus contains the cell's DNA
Bacterial cells divide through binary fission
negative_examples: The heart pumps blood through the body
She broke her arm in the accident
The brain processes sensory information
His muscles were sore after the workout
The liver filters toxins from the blood
The lungs exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Organ, Tissue, BodySystem, AnatomicalStructure

candidates.definition: Protective or functional outer structures that form the external surface of animal bodies or body parts.

positive_examples: The turtle withdrew into its hard shell when threatened.
Bird feathers provide insulation and enable flight.
The horse's hooves clattered on the cobblestone street.
Armadillo shells are made of overlapping bony plates.
Peacock feathers displayed brilliant iridescent colors.
The blacksmith fitted iron shoes to protect the horse's hooves.
negative_examples: The doctor examined the patient's internal organs.
She felt the bone beneath the skin on her arm.
The muscle tissue contracted when stimulated.
Blood vessels carried oxygen throughout the body.
The nervous system controls bodily functions.
Cartilage cushions the joints between bones.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: InternalOrgans, SkeletalStructure, MuscularSystem, CirculatorySystem

candidates.definition: Anatomical parts of the head and face region, including facial features, sensory organs, and cranial structures.

positive_examples: She touched her forehead to check for fever.
The boxer's jaw was bruised after the fight.
He raised his eyebrows in surprise at the news.
The doctor examined the patient's eardrum with an otoscope.
She applied lipstick to her lips before the date.
The surgeon repaired the damaged cornea to restore vision.
negative_examples: He flexed his biceps to show his strength.
She massaged her sore shoulders after work.
The athlete stretched his hamstring muscles.
He broke his wrist falling off the bike.
She painted her fingernails bright red.
The doctor checked his pulse at the wrist.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Arms, Legs, Torso, Hands, Feet

candidates.definition: Specialized biological structures and tissues that perform specific functions within living organisms.

positive_examples: The heart pumps blood throughout the circulatory system.
Her vocal cords vibrated as she sang the high note.
The doctor examined the patient's nervous system for damage.
Fish spawn contains thousands of eggs with nutrient-rich yolks.
His bicep muscle contracted as he lifted the weight.
The reproductive organs produce gametes for fertilization.
negative_examples: She broke her arm bone in the accident.
The skin on his face was sunburned.
He cut his finger and blood dripped out.
Her hair grew longer over the summer.
The dentist examined her teeth for cavities.
He felt the cartilage in his knee joint.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Bone, Skin, Hair, Teeth, Cartilage

candidates.definition: Relating to or involving the structural framework of bones, shells, or hard supportive elements in organisms.

positive_examples: The skeletal system provides structural support for the human body.
Marine biologists studied the crab's hard exoskeleton structure.
X-rays revealed damage to his skeletal framework after the accident.
The fossil showed remarkably preserved bone structure from millions of years ago.
Arthropods rely on their external skeletal armor for protection.
The xiphoid process is a small cartilaginous extension of the sternum.
negative_examples: She flexed her muscular arms after the workout.
The circulatory system pumps blood throughout the body.
His nervous system was affected by the medication.
The skin provides a protective barrier against infections.
Digestive enzymes break down food in the stomach.
Respiratory function was monitored during surgery.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Muscular, Circulatory, Nervous, Digestive

candidates.definition: Major structural body parts excluding the head, encompassing the trunk and appendages that enable movement and posture

positive_examples: She stretched her arms above her head and twisted her torso to the left
The dancer's graceful neck movements complemented her fluid arm gestures
He felt a sharp pain in his shoulder blade near his spine
The swimmer's powerful stroke engaged her entire torso and limbs
She wrapped her arms around her waist and hunched her shoulders
The yoga pose required balancing on one leg while extending the other
negative_examples: Her face lit up with a bright smile
The child's eyes sparkled with curiosity
He nodded his head in agreement
She had beautiful long hair cascading down
The dentist examined his teeth and gums
Her brain processed the complex information quickly
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Head, Face, Brain, Eye, Hair
